>From: Ian Badcoe <ian_badcoe@...>

> >If only I had my own beowulf cluster!!!  :)
>
>Can we still join in?  I haven't been able to access the site for some 
>days....

Currently, no.  The controller is now at work, which means it is behind the 
work firewall.  Our IT guy said he would set me up with a NATed port that 
will let me access it from the outside, but he hasn't done that yet.

And as of right now, generations are only taking about 60 seconds each.  For 
you, you would have to download the bzip'd code, decompress it, compile it, 
then fetch a work packet, then process it...  by the time you had done all 
that, the generation might be over!  If at some point I up the population 
back up to 1000 networks, the generations might take long enough to be worth 
having participants outside the corporate network...  But as long as I can 
make progress with shorter generations, I'm going to do it!

In the mean time, at around generation 1080, something cool happened.  The 
peak fitness had been almost completely flat (very, very small 
fluctuations).  But suddenly it was actually up higher, and was fluctuating 
a lot by comparison.  That lasted for about 80 generations, and then it went 
back to its quiet old self.  Which means that it CAN eventually find 
something that makes a difference.

What's unfortunate is that when it died, the new topology created to replace 
it wasn't based on the one that died.  Makes me wonder if perhaps I should 
make a slight change to how I decide which network to mutate when making new 
topologies.  Currently, I just pick an elite at random from the current 
population.  Perhaps what I should do is select the 'peak' network from 
history.  Yeah...I think I'll try that...  I'll let you know if that helps.

-- John
